Message.Title: Sales Tax and Outdated Electronics
Message.Msg: I like Amazon's business and think it is a great $35 billion dollar company, but these current valuations scream BUBBLE!!! Without the state sales tax advantage, which will be gone in most heavily populated states by this year. Amazon has no competitive advantage. It sells technology (new tablet released tomorrow and epix video contract) that are outdated before they hit the market. A tablet with a camera...how revolutionary. Amazon has only made $1.4 billion in its whole existence...that's a backward looking PE of over 100 for life. One reality check and this thing is trading in the $70-80 range...which would still be a 100 PE (very high).

Message.Title: Amazon vs Wal-Mart
Message.Msg: Amazon is taking out individual internet retailers (for obvious reasons) and will penetrate some markets that are store-based today. But what if Wal-Mart goes right at them? Wal-Mart has superior logistics, stores for product pick-up, warehousing and a topnotch fleet. How can Amazon w/home delivery compete in store-based? My guess: Amazon captures party favors and janitorial supplies and a zillion small items but not high margin big products. You will pick-up your internet-purchased flatscreen at Wally World. I'd appreciate your thoughts. Not message board boor hype. Thinking.

Message.Msg: You are in a pattern of the 2000 crash - big open up, big reversal down into the close, then crash.... Message.Title: Bezos says 22%, ISupply says 4.2%
Message.Msg: How long will the street let Bezos get away with making up stories about how well the Kindle is doing? Last week Bezos announced that the Kindle Fire had 22% of the tablet market share. ISupply now says that Amazon sold 1 million Kindle Fires for 3rd place at 4.2% If a guy is willing to tell lies about part of his business, he just might be telling lies about other parts of the business. Why does the 'professional' business press let him get away with this?
